text: Bottled 1 pt 6 fl oz at Haket, Göteborg, on June 16, 2017. Many thanks to Michael for sharing his bottle!Cloudy brown color, off-white head. Malty, sweet, alcohol, toffee scent. Sweet, alcohol, bitter, pith, harsh taste. Malty, sweet aftertaste. Warming alcohol. Full smooth mouthfeel, high bitterness.7/2/6/4/12=3.1

bottle - Pours amber with a malty, grainy, slightly fruity aroma. The flavor is sweet, bready, vaguely grainy, citrusy, and moderately bitter in the end. Interesting beer. It works pretty well. Old notes... had this one sometime last year. I dont know how it would be holding up now as it says to drink fresh.
Pours dark Amber with moderate carbonation. Lasting foam prelude to plum with moderately dry finish. Wish I had gotten it a little fresher.

Pine, resin, overripe tropical fruits, molasses, dates, dark, dried fruits. Clear, dark gold, small, creamy, white head. Creamy caramel malts, bittersweet orange, soft carbonation, full bodied. Nice Speciality Grain, quite intense on malts. Keg at BrewDog, Manchester.

22-ounce bottle pours clear amber with a small light tan head with no lacing. Aroma: toffee, dark bread, nuts, malt, faint hops. Flavor: bubblegum, caramel, caramelized brown sugar, layers of maltiness that is hard to pinpoint -- due to the grain bill of barley, wheat, millet, buckwheat, oats and triticale. Mouthfeel is rich. slick and savory with a boozy warmth that lingers. Still, a bit too sweet for me.

Two things you never want to see next to each other on a beer bottle: a born-on date from eighteen months ago, and "DRINK FRESH" on the labeling. So, safe to say, Im not approaching Grainiac under optimum conditions. But damned if that liquor store didnt have a large selection of old Stone beers for super-cheap, and damned if I didnt buy a wide variety of them. So now, aged Grainiac: malt-bomb is right, at least as far as the nose goes; huge toffee-caramel malts with underlying booze and a grainy earthiness I cant quite place. Pour isnt all that pretty, dark brown but with little head and lacing and a worrying amount of particulate swirling around the pint. Taste opens up with a syrupy smack of malt, caramel and honey and sweet tea, growing a strange, rye-like tang on the back end. Nutty middle fades into a oat-cluster sweetness on the finish, offset by a firm dry hoppiness once likely a source of citric complexity but now flat pine. Fade is bready and full, like a honey-slathered piece of 12-grain loaf covered in pine needles. Textures remarkably smooth and easy, even if theres an unexpected boozy heat for an 8.5% brew. Not bad. Wish I couldve tried it fresh.
Amazing. Slightly thick. Hint of sour, with lots of caramel/malt . Cloudy, little foam.

Keg Third of a Pint at BrewDog, Shepherds Bush, London in April 2016 - Dark Reddish Amber in colour. Massive rocky off-white beige head. Excellent lacing. Very Malty; toasty malts, grainy, rye, wheaty, nutty, caramel. Quite Spicy. Fruity; grapefruit citrus. Hoppy; earthy and piney hops. Bittersweet very grainy malty spicy and citrus fruity throughout. Nicely executed. Enjoyed this. Good stuff. Nice grainy malty and citrus fruity IPA! (2016-04-05)
Good stuff. Amber color with a small head. Nice weight and carbonation. Aromas and flavors of grain, wheat, rye and some other spice. Nutty and citrus from the hops.
on tap at Brewdog Sheffield. Red-brown colour. long standing foam. Citrus aroma, low roastiestones. Sweet caramel ,roasty sugar herbs, low fruity, alcohol, still easygoing and low bittery.

Bottle pour into nonic pint glass from Cigarette City. Appearance is cloudy red with minimal sparkle, ephemeral beige head with trace lacing. Aroma is dank resin, pungent citrus bordering on acetone, light alcohol and floral over bread/caramel malts. Taste is much like the aroma. Palate is medium bodied with thick, slightly slippery texture, spiciness from the rye, soft carbonation and finish like the taste. Overall, maybe sometimes there are too many ingredients. Theres no cohesive message here.
Exceeding my expectations, this beer has an interesting mixture of flavors. Mostly sweet and malty.like an amber, but overly.ao, it has enough hops to end. A bit boozy at the end but pretty solid.

For a lot of reasons I will be the black sheep here and say this was a fantastic beer in every way. The appearacne is a rich and polished mohagany/amber with an off-white head of creamy foam. The aromas open with caramel, toffee, sweet bread, some fruitfullness similar to peaches and light plum. The hops are reserved until the end where they alter sweet fruit toward slightly tart and dry for an all around enjoyable revolution. The tasting provided more heavy notes of sweet malts and light stone fruit counterbalanced by the citrus and pine hops balancing it all out.
Amber off white head. Nose is stone fruit, a little dank, caramel. Flavor is bitter, caramel, rye spice, a little grassy wheat, apricot. Medium body, light for the alcohol, a little heat. Great.
Aroma of nutty, smoky hops w/ a bit of malt. Nice appearance... tastes of malt, grain, floral hops.. Fairly balanced, nice complexity. Very smooth, a hint of bitter. Its good.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized tan colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a typically carbonated very hazy dark brown orange colored body and a good lacing. The weak aroma was hoppy and malty. The crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a lingering hoppy aftertaste. The nice flavor contained notes of rye old ale brown malt hops and bread dough. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

Tap at Sedona. Pours slightly hazy Amber. Aroma of red licorice, citrus. Taste is alcohol based liquified red licorice and some orange. A bit syrupy for stone. Finishes bitter. Not a favorite. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Sedona Taphouse (Charlottesville, VA). Aromas of caramel, biscuit, toast, red berries, grape, a little tropical. Hazy red with a somewhat lasting white head. A tad sweet, bready, pretty well balanced, fruity hop flavors, somewhat floral, grainy. Medium-full bodied.

BOTTLE. Pours a ruby colour with creamy off white head.. Malt dominant nose, creamy musky vibes.. Robust malt body, minimal hoppy middle, slight bitterness, earthy big malts throughout, malty.. Sourced cellarbrations @ capel

Found a bottle on the shelf at a discount and am very pleased. Dark amber in color, hoppy aroma. Full of sweet malt flavor with just the right amount of hops to balance it out. Sweet taste with a slight bitter finish.
A malt bomb with caramel that is both sweet and bitter. Ends with nice hoppy aroma and bitterness. Unusual, but nice.

Bottle. It poured a copper color with a white head. The aroma was of floral hops, bready and toffee. The taste was similar to the aroma with more floral hops, sweet juices, bread, malts and some grains. Pretty interesting. Tasty.

650ml bottle. Pours a hazy red-amber with a large, creamy, long lasting, beige head
that leaves plenty of lace. Sweet aroma of caramel malt, bread, peach, rye and grapefruit. Sweet flavour of caramel malt, peach, rye, citrus and pine with a dry, bitter, hop resin finish. Medium body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Kind of weird but well made.
Poured from the bomber, looks a murky brown with a hint of orange. Has a malty orange sweetness with hops and some booze. Nice and strong, dry at the end, another successful project.

bomber from binnys Lincoln Park. malty nose, beautiful clear dark reddish amber, barley wine sweetness, rye spiciness, in fact nutty, hoppy. liked the concept, loved the story behind the name, see, from The Stone Blog: http://www.stonebrewing.com/blog/beer/2015 /stochasticity-project-grainiac which includes http://www.stonebrewing.com/sites/default/files /ttb_-_grainiac3_0.png

Clear amber color with a foamy white head. Lots of roasted malt aroma and toasted wood which follow into the taste. Fairly heavy body with a creamy texture. More wood with a molasses sweetness and a deep alcohol flavor rolls over the tongue and lays down for awhile. Earthy, leafy bitterness comes through mid-sip. Finishes with vanilla and more wood. Theres lots of good things here, but they dont really come together in a coherent way.
Pour is caramel color all most like apple cider with a small tan head. Aroma is sweet and hoppy. A nice balance between hops and malts
East of Everything ontap(16-Jun-16)Candy spice light wood aroma.Dark red,creamy lasting head&fluffy lace.Wood sweet berry malt flavour.Spiced wood and funny aftertaste.
Slight hop candy aroma. Deep Amber colour great head and lacing. Malt herbal candy spice flavour. Smooth palate.

Pours a hazed amber. Aroma is nice as usual with stone, with citrus and floral. Earthy grainy malt. Taste is hoppy, complex grain but refined, dry toast, nutty, earthy. Bit of boozy finish, having the other half I didnt have yesterday, I remember thinking this was like a barleywine. I think these grains would go good in a dark beer, but an ipa might be interesting. Not that this isnt hoppy or anything.This is good but not one of stones better ones and if Rogue did it, then it would probably not be as good as this. What Im trying to say here is Rogue has a tendency to fail with the experimental ones, but I do like some of Rogues stuff, like Beard beer, but not voodoo doughnut. etc..

Copper-reddish colored, clear, medium- off white creamy head. Aroma is sweet malt, cereal, lots of cracker, some toasty notes, some citrus and floral hops, rye. Taste is medium+ sweet malts, caramel, rye, toasty, very malty, cereals, medium citrus and floral piney hoppy aroma and bitterness, dryish. Medium to full bodied, soft carbonation, oily.

10 oz at WoB. pours a dark brown with red tints and a well formed head. The aroma is powerful with pungent hop blast of grapefruit and pine. Hefty malt provides a complex and welcome balance. The body is creamy and pretty full. Well realized notes of grapefruit highlight malty notes of caramel, biscuits, berries, and a little chocolate. This is like a more complex Arrogant Bastard.

Wow, a multigrain lineup including unusual ingredients like buckwheat, triticale, and millet, along with the more traditional rye, oats, and wheat. It does not seem to have any barley in it. The results are superb - I wonder what kind of yeast was used. It is smooth but strong, with notes of apricot, fig, and brown sugar. The hops are clearly present but dont overshadow the malts. The different elements connect seamlessly. This could be my favorite in the Stone Stochasticity series.
UPDATED: JUN 13, 2016 Tap. Hazy, amber, minimal head, white foam, medium bitterness, light sweetness, medium body, oily feel, average carbonation, & bitter finish.

Hazed amber, laced light beige head. As balanced as an aroma can get...pine but ripe berries. Nice on the tongue. Some cherry up front, yielding to a nice resin, earthy malt combo. Dry finish....great!

Bottle, 650ml. A reddish beer with a small brown head and some sediments. Grainy aromas with spices, malt and earthy notes. Taste is bitter with moderate carbonation. Medium bodied, dry and astrigent. Complex aftertaste, grainy and bitter.

Bottle, 650ml. Clear maple with visibile sediment and a frothy to creamy tan head. Earthy aromas of toffee, roasted caramel, dried fruits. Medium to robust bodied with moderate carbonation. Medium sweet with heavy bitterness. Roasted and alcohol character into an astringent hoppy finish. Unique and delicious.

Choc and hop aroma fill my nose with this hazy Amber brew with a nice off white head. Earthy choc sweet barley wine flavor with a moderate bitterness and medium heavy body comes with this brew. Not bad.

Bottle:
Cloudy, brown, with a thick beige head.
Rye, bready aroma......a little peel.
Taste is sweet and malty....followed by a decent citrus/herbal bitter.
Rye malt, caramel malt, bread....
Pretty nice.....creamy...drinks easily for the ABV.

Nearly six-month old bomber. Pours unfiltered amber with medium-sized sediment. Nose of light caramel, wet earth, gentle coffee, faded ripe and floral dry hop, ménage of wheat and oatiness. Flavor is mildly sweet and juicy, malt provides a nice depth of toastiness and soft coffee to molasses, caramel, and wildflower honey. Old as hell and still enjoyable.

17th March 2016Brewdog Shepherd Bush. Keg. Almost clear reddish amber beer, good cream colour head. Palate is smooth and mildly dry, reasonable fine carbonation. Smooth malts, a little dry cream. Mild rye spice. Red berries and mild marmalade. Strong pine hops and some hop spice. Bitterish toffee and citric peel on the finish. Hangs together very well. Very tasty.

Draft @ BrewDog Shepherds Bush, Shepherds Bush W12. Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty peachy hoppy caramel aroma. Fruity malty peachy hoppy caramel spicy flavor. Has a fruity malty hoppy bitter peachy caramel finish.

At Stone Brewing Total Tap Takeover at The Rover yesterday (April 18, 2016) I got to try this beer. 

A little hazy, red beer with a thin head. 
Lot of malt here! Caramel, grain, rye, citrus, pine and wheat. 
Medium body and carbonation. Dry ending. 

Lovely!

Draught at St. Augustines, Vancouver; 414mlCloudy amber color, thin head. Nice aroma, malty, a bit fruity. The body is strong, it has a moderate level of sweetness, strong flavor from different grains, then strong hopping. A bit too earthy in the final.Not my favorite, but well made anyway.
On tap at the rover, Göteborg. Amber with off white head. Grain, citrus and herbs. Dry with medium bitterness and medium carbonation.

Draught at The Rover, Göteborg. Hazy amber beer with a nice offwhite head. Malty grainy aroma, bready, citrus notes, herbal, some dark bread. Malty grainy aroma, grassy notes, citrus, some dark bread. Ok.
Bottle @ Hakets Ölfestival. Dark amber with a tiny off white head. Fruity and hoppy tones. Fruit, malt, caramel and hops. Full body with a balanced finish.

Amber hazy body with a frothy white head. Aroma is sweet and grassy. Body is sweet and full with floral notes.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Keg at Musa, Aberdeen. It pours murky deep brown with a medium white head. The aroma is bitter - sweet, pine needles, toffee, orange marmalade, candied peel and sherbet. The taste is bitter - sweet, pine needles, resinous, alcohol boost, toffee, caramel, spicy action, leather, citrus peel and fruit cake with a lingering bitter - dry finish. Medium - full body and moderate carbonation. Pretty punchy stuff.

Keg, Brewdog Leicester. Golden brown with an off white head. Nutty with dark toffee and multigrain. Sandalwood with herbal, pine aspects. Spiced oranges with brown bread. Nice peppery booze. Good beer.
Bottle. Orange, cherry, rye, malt and grapefruit peel aroma. Amber with small head. Sweet orange, rye malt, and moderately bitter grapefruit peel flavor. Nice body.
Amber pour. Resiny pine and citrus in the finish. Malty and caramel like an Amber ale. The specialty grains arent lending much character hee.
22oz bottle. Poured a hazy deeper amber color with an off white head. Bread, earthy, caramel, and some citrus.
Keg at Brewdog Shepherds Bush, London. An amber/brown coloured pour with a medium beige head on top. Sweet, malty, caramel on the nose. Tastes hoppy, nutty, malty, caramel. Decent.

on tap @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Aroma of fresh malt. Clear amber brown tan head cover, hanging strands of lace. Taste is full-bodied malt that reminds me of cask-conditioned. Moves through a medium carbonated swallow to a finish that has plenty of clean hops to balance. Fresh, full-bodied, light in the belly, complex, a superb brew.
Looks like cognac. Smells weird has a plasticy grain taste. Cheers for trying.

Tap @ Brewdog, Soho. Unclear brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and moderate hoppy - grapefruit and earthy. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. 230316

Keg at BD Mighty Boosh, 21/03/16.
Rich amber with a decent beige cap.
Nose is caramel, earthy hops, pine needle, grapefruit zest, bready notes.
Taste comprises caramel malt, faint spice, toffee, good hop coating, toasted brown sugar, pine resin. 
Medium + bodied, fine carbonation, semi aggressive hop bitterness in the close. 
Decent DIPA (bollocks to the assigned style by a room full of kangaroo court judges) .. delivers a boost as promised.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: On tap at St. Augustines. Pours a clear deep amber. Aroma and taste are sweet & bitter, citrusy (sweet orange), caramel. Rich hoppy bitterness aftertaste. Very good balanced. Almost excellent.

On tap at St. Augustines, pours a nearly opaque orange amber with a small beige head. Aroma is very grainy and earthy, with all sorts of dark earthy grains showcasing along with a considerable hop profile. Flavour is along the same lines, with caramel malt upfront, followed by a very earthy toasted grain presence and resinous hops. Fairly spicy with the different grains. Well-constructed but a tad abrasive. Good.
Honey fruit on the nose , this is a perfect blend of sweet and sour , this is amazingly easy to drink .

Clear, dark brown colour. Tan head, about one finger thick. Sweet aroma, syrup, malts, but the aroma is not very strong though. Taste is malty, very strong taste with hoppy aftertaste. Soft carbonation. Really good beer overall.

Bottle half off at Haskells. Pours ruby brown with a thin sudsy film. Aroma is grain and filed hops light citrus pine and spent malt. Taste is bitter diluted citrus pine hops and malty spent grain. Palate is full and a touch sticky. Not bad for being 4 months old.
Light and sweet. Scent of grain, malt, and iron. Hazy, wooden color. Thin head. Long-lasting bitterness.

Bomber. Pours a deep dark amber with a medium sized cream colored head. Aroma of grapefruit, rye, cola, wheat, toffee, grains and hops. Taste of Cascade and Centennial hops, grapefruit, rye, wheat, toffee and buckwheat.
a strong caramel and mix of tropical fruit flavor stimulate appetite. A little over- full of the bitter taste in the mouth overwhelmed entire flavor. Pretty straight forward and simple
pretty complex, strong beer overall. Hoppy, but can feel the cereal aroma. Liked it a lot.
Brownish color. A bit strong. Sweet caramel aroma. A little bit dry fruit. Medium carbonation
Poured bomber into Teku. Unfortunately the aroma has died out (3.5m after bottling). Strong malty backbone with a good balance of hops. Liking it better as it warms up.

Tap at craft Edmonton. An oddball but tasty. Nose is rye peppery and grain. Flavours of millet (had a millet based scotch lately very similar, syrup. Taste med/big bitter light/med sweet. Full body medium csrbonation and some lasting alcohol heat and bitterness in finish.

22 oz bottle pours an amber color with a nice white head. Aromas of ctitus, pine, with sweet malt in the background. Medium bodied, nicely balanced.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, as pictured. Bought it at a discount, definitely worth the $4 for a bomber. Deep and dark, heavy, has a barleywine feel to it. I know its not supposed to be but thats what I got from it. Dont really get a ton of the hops but might be because its a few months old now. Either way a nice beer.
Keg at Doghouse. Pours ruby amber with a slight white head. Aroma is caramel and toffee. Taste is resin, toffee, caramel, earthy, pine and slightly bitter.

Draft. Pours a medium thick, well retained, tiny bubbled, light beige head, over a clear, light copper (SRM 14) body......nose is pine, resin, light floral honey notes from the hops, heavy toasted malts, with bread, cereal, no esters, balanced.......taste is moderately sweet with multiple toasted malted grain notes, rye spice, mild toffee/caramel, bread, moderate pine, resin, tangerine, licorice, pineapple from the hops, ending with mild bitterness, balance slightly to the hops........mouth feel, slightly sticky, medium thick body, moderate alcohol, mild astringency creamy carbonation. The multiple grains are slightly muddled, but make for an interesting malt backbone, to balance the complex hop contribution. BJCP 8/3/15/4/8
Amber beer with a malty, tropical aroma. The aroma matches the scent more than the taste does. Flavour is citrus fruits, a bit of a rye beer quality and a hit of hop. Very nice.
Bottle. Pours copper with a creamy white head. Aromas of floral hops and foffee. Flavors are toffee, toasted malt, toasted grains, nuttiness, and resiny hops. Full and rich. Delicious.

22oz bottle poured into a snifter. Garnet color with a slight haze and a creamy off white head. Dank, piney hop aromas with some citrus. Thick and viscous mouthfeel. Spicy rye and earthy flavors up front followed by noticeable hop bitterness with grapefruit notes. Overall a pretty intense and complex beer. Tastes better than I thought it might with the unusual grain bill, but it seems to work well, especially with the high dose of hops.
On tap at Archive. An orangish, amber brew with floral and citrus aroma over the top of the malts. The malts blend together quite nicely on the palate and are well balanced by the hops. Delish.

Hmmmm, toss me into the category of "likes this" one. Despite it being a very grainy beer, it does not come across as a terrible malt bomb, which is a nice relief. Poured a clear orange-amber color with a small white head. Aroma was light floral notes, chewy grains, light spicy rye notes. Flavor was very similar. Light floral hops, grain. Bready. Alcohol well masked in this one.

Bottle. Rusty orange, medium body. Big, rustic aroma, like a freshly painted wood shop. This drinks with a classic Stone kick-in-the-pants, heavily laden with the BIG malt undertow. I think you could strip paint with this. (#6132, 2/17/2016)
Draft - Pours amber white head - nose/taste of buckwheat, rye, granola cake, citrus and florals - medium body

22 ounce bottle. Garnet colored pour with a moderate creamy beige head that levels a clinging lace. Rich earthy malt nose has hints of caramel, butter and toasted nuts. Bittersweet toasted malt upfront. Earthy grain notes of rye and buckwheat are evident. Complex and spicy. Hoppy notes in finish are fruity with notes of citrus and vanilla. Quite delicious.

22 oz. bottled Nov 13, 2015. Big nose of sticky resin, toffee, injera, earthy walnut, dry cocoa, peppery toast and grapefruit. Clear copper body has a thin disc of cream on top. Tastes of earthy toffee, pine resin, toasted nut, grapefruit with the peppery zest, buckwheat pancakes and dates. Medium-heavy body has smooth medium carbonation and a very drinkable balance that leans to the dry side on the finish.

Tap, bocktown. A darker brew like dark iced tea. Slight sweet perfume aroma. Nice lacing. Bitter sharp strong initial impressions. Nasty nellie, needs manners my friend. Quite like a rye that tastes like an IPA. Mouthcoating, bitter.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bomber shared by Marcus. Pours bright dark copper with a beige head. Aroma is sort of brown sugar. With some fruity hop. Med body or a bit more. Flavor is odd malt, some mint hint, stone fruits, brown sugar, Quite interesting, mothering wrong with it, but it isnt really hitting on all 12 cylinders with me. But on the other hand Im now understanding the rye spice - so the cylinders are starting to synchronize.
Bottle from Capitol Beer & Tap Room. Pours orange brown with a thick beige head and a grainy brown sugar aroma. There is a sweet mixed malt flavor, hevy on the rye, with a more bitter finish.

Small (1 or 2 oz.) pour, from a 22 oz. bottle, at Beer Dabbler Winter Carnival. Consumed on 2-6-16. Pours a hazy amber with beige head. Effervescence. Malty, hoppy aroma features a tropical fruit scent. Pleasant, fresh smell. Strong Amber Ale taste. Malty and hoppy. Caramel flavor. Good but a little much in flavor. Grainy (appropriately) and lively in the palate. Medium to full body.

1/28/16. On tap, World of Beer, Destin. Amber pour with a nice khaki head, good lacing. Malty aroma, complex, earthy, caramel, toffee, soft wheat, citrus. Okay flavor, malty, doughy, bready, granola, caramel, citrus. Not bad.
On tap at the Sanctuary. I do love Stone beers, but this one didnt really work for me. I found it harsh and "grainy"--no pun on the name

The working name of "Colon Blow" is comical but this beer is no joke. It pours a cloudy brown and had a nice citrus hopped taste with a strong caramel finish. It went will with my taco dinner and better with my pretzel dessert.

Pours a clear amber with an antique lace head. Aroma is pine. Taste is sweet caramel malt, sour grapefruit, butteriness, a slightly odd medicinal quality, and an assertive bitterness. ABV comes through as warmth after the swallow.

Amber color with a thin off white head. Aroma is strongly of bread with a bit of hops and a bit of alcohol sweetness. Flavor is a bit boozy with strong grain flavors. Almost similar to a rye bread or multigrain. Bitter hops in the finish.
Bottle, shared with Parksy. Reddish orange, golden head. Big grapefruit and pine, spicy undertones, also maybe some stonefruit sweetness, controlled bitterness. Really good.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 22 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 11/13/2015. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy dark ruby red/copper color with a 2 finger dense and rocky khaki head with great retention and reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, caramel, brown sugar, wheat, toasted biscuit, spicy rye, light nuttiness, and floral/grassy earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of juicy citrus/pine hops and dark/bready malt notes; with good strength. Taste of big grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, caramel, brown sugar, wheat, toasted biscuit, spicy rye, light nuttiness, and floral/grassy earthiness. Moderate pine/citrus rind bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, pineapple, lemon/orange peel, pine, caramel, brown sugar, wheat, toasted biscuit, spicy rye, and floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a while. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of juicy citrus/pine hops and dark/bready malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero astringent hop flavors after the finish. Light-moderate dryness from bitterness that increases through the glass. Medium carbonation and medium-full body; with a very smooth, and moderately creamy/bready/sticky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent imperial amber ale style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of juicy citrus/pine hops and dark/bready malt flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink for the ABV. A very enjoyable offering.

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co., and snifter served showing a clear, deep copper color, with a frothy layer of tan head foam, and doily-like lacing. The nose was fruity as dried, dark cherry, hefty malt and some sweetness, with ready alcohol. Medium+ bodied with average carbonation, and decent alcohol presence, the taste added a dry, earthy, and rind-like bitterness that lingered into a dry & dusty finish. Liked it.

22 oz bottle shared by DrSilverworm. Pours a clear dark amber color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have big grainy malts as advertised, herbal, earthy, some West Coast citrus character, grapefruit zest, caramel, bitterness grew as it warmed, interesting enough beer.

Heavy aroma of grain, especially the wild, rustic aroma of rye. Hops are moderate with herb and resin aromas, unusual...

Reddish brown, clear color with an average sized off-white head.

Moderately sweet and bitter.

Medium to full bodied; average carbonation; long bitter finish.

Overall a somewhat unusual flavor profile, reminiscent of a rye beer. Not great, but interesting and pretty good.

Pours a reddish brown with a thin off white head. Nose is complex grains, like a mixed grain cereal, and sweet malt. Dried fruit notes. Taste is balanced. Good brew.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep amber pour with creamy tan head and lace. Aroma is sweet malt with a touch of fruitiness. Flavor is very sweet malt with a touch perfumy notes. A very large bitter finish. Smooth carbonation for a real experience swirl it aroun in your mouth like you would listerine.

Dark clear amber with a beige bubbly head. Aroma of rye, caramel, bread, and earth. Taste is very malt forward but not really sweet and just barely bitter; the "specialty" grains come through rather nicely. Medium bodied, very slightly dry, and slick.

Poured from bomber. Pours amber with an off white head. Aroma is fruity malt with herbal, earthy, spicy, hops. Flavor is grainy malt, dry caramel malt, fruit and citrus with a dry earthy, piney hop finish and rye.

22oz bomber pours with a clear amber to ruby red colored body that supports a tan head of foam. The aroma offers up inviting spicy hops, floral hops, some crystal malts, sweet graininess and then a sliver of citrus. The taste delivers a pleasing blend of sweet crystal malts, spicy hoppy bitterness and then softer citrus hop, an earthy spicy hoppiness and floral hop notes. The malts take on a bit of added sweetness to midway and into the finish. Interesting beer where the earthy to spicy hops take center stage and thats totally fine with me.
An American Strong /Barley Wine masquerading as specialty grain. Color is nice, clear copper. Nose is malt driven. Palate is oily and sweet and cloying. Meh.

Dark Amber in color... Aroma of caramel, toffee, citrus hops... Flavor is malt forward, lots of bready tones throughout, citrusy hops on palate... Some spice from rye malts... Couldn't point out the buckwheat or millet, but I doubt anyone can... Decent, nothing that exciting

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft. Rich amber beer with a dark cream head. Caramel aroma with grapefruit and pine. Grapefruit and pine flavor with caramel. Medium bodied. Caramel and light toffee lingers with grapefruit and pine.
nice reddish-brown color; great citrusy hop aroma with underlying bready malt; sme piney hop notes; well balanced

Pours a dark, reddish-copper, with middling head. Aroma is very grassy, malty, almost woody. Flavor is sweet and bitter and has some citrus, some nuts, some malt, but ultimately reminds me most of some of my homebrew failures. I expect more from Stone.

22oz bottle pours a murky brown with plenty of creamy, grey head. Nose has some cooked greens, mild malt, bread, light spice, anise, sumac. Flavor is malt, grainy, light acid, a bit off. Creamy finish. Weird.
Bottle at the nuplastikk returns tasting in VA. Clear amber with off-white head. Aromas of floral notes, grains, oats. Tastes of floral notes, grains, malt, light corn. Medium body with a dry finish.

On tap at Albertsons. Big malty nose like a barleywine. Dark amber/copper color with foamy beige head. Head settles to a small creamy skin. Taste also features the malt, and lots of instant heat also. If not for the diverse grain bill, this could challenge in the barleywine category. A malt bomb for sure.

Sampled on draft this beer poured a brown color with a faint orange hue and a small creamy orange-white head that left excellent lacing. The aroma was lightly fruity with a hint of toffee. The flavor was tart, bitter and watered down with a cheap whiskey note and a bit of vague fruit and sour caramel. Long cheap whiskey finish. Thin, watery and a bit flat in body. Not good.
Bottle. Slightly hazy amber color, off white head. Aroma of lightly spiced and bready citrus. Taste is spiced lemon and raw white bread. OK.
From a 22 oz bottle shared at the 2016 Nuplastik is back tasting. Pours a clear orange gold with an off white head. Aroma of caramel. Flavors of caramel and citrus. Nice.
Some caramel. Some light roast. Light sweet finish. Not bad but not super my thing. Heavy malt presence.
Brown-amber pour with a thin head. The aroma is malty, a little roasted and maybe even some smoke. Flavor is mild to strong with hops and alcohol throughout. Lots of caramel and an alcoholic heat.

Pours a cloudy reddish-brown colour with an off white half inch head that left thin lacing. Aroma is sweet citrus and nutty malts with woody/ grainy backing notes. Flavor is a slightly different story. Buckwheat and fruits linger in a dry nutty and herbal hopped blend that leads to an astringent and bitter finish. Medium bodied, this brew is initially inviting, but becomes another kind of monster as the malts take control with a woody vengeance.

Pours clear chestnut with a fairly thick and frothy pale tan head. Aroma presents strong fruity, malty and woody tones. Bold flavor has a fruity core, apple and pear and a little citrus, which supports a malty chord and a firm note of woody, slightly bitter hops. Grain-iac indeed! Mouthfeel features average body but good, strong fizz and a nice hoppy and malty finish. Its a grainiac, grainiac in your mouth.
22 ounce bottle. Bottled two months ago. Red in color. Some malt and caramel. Slight bitter sweet. Some hops. Nice. Not as big of a cascade punch as I expected.
On draft at Stone. Dark amber pour, with a light beige head. Bready, surprisingly hoppy, grapefruit, fruity, caramel, grain, earthy, rye, wheat, and bitterness in the finish.

Deep gorgeous Amber with a tight light beige cap. Really interesting aroma with lots of nutty earthy tones, rustic milled granola-esque graininess, with a strong floral and grapefruit rind hoppy bitter presence on the nose as well. Big dry and butter flavor with lots of earthy grainy flavors, buckwheat, dry nutty bitterness, with a bitter floral and grapefruity tone underneath. Weirdly enough its as if the hoppy citrusy and resiny flavors are the ones giving the sweetness, while the dry nutty grainy malts are the ones weirdly providing bitterness.

650ml bottle from Jims in Mundelein. 11/8/2015 "bottled on" date. Fresh! Dark amber pour with a bit of an off-white head. Aroma has fruits, sweet malts, some grassiness and some different grains. Taste is of sweet malts, sweet fruits, some nuts, some resiny chewiness, and different grains. Sweet and dry as a bone, with some hoppiness. Medium bodied with a bit of an alcohol presence. Finishes sweet and dry. Solid, tasty, interesting effort. 13.7
Really good. A nice mix of malt and hops. Stone does it again woth a really adventurous beer.

On tap at Hops and Pie poured a clear reddish amber with a small lasting creamy amber head. Aromas of caramel, earthiness and citrus. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of caramel, earthiness and light fruitiness with a crisp dry lingering caramel finish.

Bomber into tulip glass, cloudy orangy-amber color with tan head. Aroma notes of caramel malt sweetness, rye grain, some toast and citrus/pine hops. Taste adds graininess, oat creaminess, slight nuttiness and grapefruit/grass bitterness. Medium body, low-moderate carbonation, creamy, soft with a grainy pine finish. Interesting grain depth with nice hop balance, tasty.

Pours amber/copper collored with a lot of foam. The aroma is very mild. Theres some caramel and rye and a little bit of floral hops. The rye come through loud and clear in the flavor. The wheat is there, too, and the hops are huge in the finish. This tastes, to my palate, like an American strong ale brewed with rye. I dont taste the buckwheat and millet, but probably wouldnt know what to look for even if I did.

I had this at UNO in Deptford, NJ (Thanks, George and Tommy!). It was a 10 oz pour that highlighted a nice head and red color. Not a ton on the nose, but the hop punch was great and the mellow, malt finish was balanced with excellence. My past experience with hoppy red ales were not good - harsh and with plenty of acid down the throat. Honestly, it was Stones name that allowed me to take a shot. What a treat on tap, too. Too bad its a limited brew in bottle bombers at this time. If you are near the Deptford Mall area, stop by for one...while it lasts. Cheers!

Bottle to pint glass. Look is deep dark brown; creamy white head. Aroma is pine and hops. Taste is malt, bread. Hop like bite in the finish. Feel is a little flat, a little sticky, but smooth.

Interesting flavors. Definitely a unique beer.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, clear dark red pour with off white head, aroma brought notes of citrus, pine, grass into a bit of biscuit, toast, slight husky notes as well. Taste was a mix of grass, orange, earth, spice into a bit of caramel, toffee, slight toast, finishing slightly bitter, slightly sweet. A pleasant surprise.
Pours a dark amber. Has a faint aroma of malts and grains. Has a sweet taste with strong caramel and some citrus hops. A decent aftertaste with lots of grains and citrus hops.

From bottle to glass. Pours a clear amber with light khaki head that lingers across the top. Very unique aroma with the different grains clearly at play here and leading to scents of spice, wheat, and also the hops shining through as citrus. Taste is rich and malty with fantastic support from the hops.

Bomber from Beer Run. Hazy dark orange amber, thin foamy tan head, decent retention. Aroma of grain, caramel, oats, citrus. The taste is bitter citrus hops, caramel. Medium bodied, lingering bitterness.
Bottle. Wow, I really dig this one. Very fruity with red fruits and spruce. Perfect mouthfeel as well. Looks nice in the glass too with a big beige head. Cheers
Drinks like a barley wine: big boozy, malty and good hop finish. Very sweet yet still balanced.

From the 650 ml. bottle dated 11/08/15. Big deep amber pour under a full cream colored head. The aroma is subtle but it brings out roasted malts and grassy hops. The mouthfeel is medium to better. The taste tends to harp upon the hop character, which usurps the sweet, caramel malt character one gets at first. Good bitterness.

Bottle: The aroma consists of has moderate pepper, light rye, wood, citrus, and pine. It pours a lightly hazed amber with a two finger orange tinted off-white head that has great retention. There is some sticky webbing left on the sides of the glass. The flavor starts with a quick dose of light caramel and fruit. The finish is moderately woody mixed with light-moderate rye, nuts, grapefruit, and pine. Its medium bodied with light-moderate carbonation and a somewhat soft mouthfeel. Overall, they probably brewed exactly what they were going for, but this really isnt my thing.
Bottle. Amber with off white head. Lots of grain with piney and citrusy hops. Medium mouthfeel. Pretty good.

Location: 22 oz bottle from Hoboken Vine, 12/22/15


Aroma: The aroma is citrus hop up-front, moving into some sort of spice / bread / rye type thing

Appearance: Pours a brownish-orange color with a sheeting beige head, and heavy, spotting lace

Flavor: Flavor-wise, lightly sweet, a lot of of spice / rye / bread / grain and a mid-bitter close

Palate: Medium bodied, average-to-lively carbonation, and a strong spicy, rye feel to the close

Overall Impression: 
Colon Blow is a pretty solid name and a pretty funny SNL skit. Grainiac is an alright name too. Also, this has to have been the biggest lock of all time for the specialty grain style. As for the beer, its got some stuff happening for sure, which is a statement that says nothing. That stuff is rye spice and bread and more grains. Yep, itll blow your colon unless youre a real grainiac.

It pours on the dark side of amber, but not quite brown with an off white head. There is plenty of lacing on the side of the glass. It has aromas of grapefruit, citrus, floral flavors, a bit of caramel, nuts, and a bit of rye. The flavors are a complex balance between the rye, caramel flavors, the grapefruit and floral accents. There are also nutty and earthy notes in the flavors as well. The feel is medium with a moderately bitter finish.

Bottle. Copper pour with a medium, dense tan head. Sweet malt and caramel laced with resinous hops and citrus fruit in the aroma. Taste is citrus, hop resins, sweet malt, pine, grains, dark bread and floral notes. Body is medium and slightly chewy with lots of oiliness and lingering hop bitterness. Ends with more caramel, chewy malt, grains, bread, floral hops,ripe citrus, hop oils and pine resins.

650ml bottle pours amber in color with a finger and a half of white head that leaves some spotted lacing on the glass. Aroma is citrus and pine with some caramel and other grains. Taste is a grapefruit and pine bitterness with a caramel malty sweetness. Grainy mouth feel. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, a well crafted and tasty brew that offers some unique features to a brew that I recommend to others.

Dark amber color. Thick tan head that leaves nice lacing. Aroma is slightly hoppy. Earthy, woody aroma. Some citrusy notes. Thick texture. Slight hops in the beginning that follows up with a bready finish. Average carbonation. I am noticing some cocoa later on in the flavor. Interesting beer but melds well together.

Bottle from Brewtopia. Amber with beige lasting head and lace. Mild spicy bready aroma. Bready grainy peachy caramel nutty sweetness with mild fruity herbal finish that lingers. Full creamy body. Complex and delicious. Very hearty yet refined. Everything works well together. Excellent.

650 ml bottle. I like the label artwork. Color is dark brown with light head around the edge of the glass. Aroma is slight cereal grains, rye and a good amount of pine powered hops.  
The flavor is deep layers of malt with dark fruits, spicy rye and traces of citrus hops. Pine bitterness helps with the balance of the heavy grains. The spicy rye also give this a much needed burst of character. The gravity seemed lighter for the first 8 or 9 ounces. After 14 ounces the Alcohol caught up to me. I liked this better more on the cooler side, as it warmed the spicy rye becomes overbearing.

Bottle from Sprouts: Poured a stunning dark amber hue topped with a thick pillow of foam cap. Aroma was mild with an obvious fragrance of grains, oats, and bread like malts while a touch of sweet caramel lurks in the distance. The beer taste of rye and hearty grained wheat bread and drinks smoothly with a refined carbonation level across my palate. The taste also comes across as sweet with a delicate backing of caramel malts too. Loved how they listed the grains used on the bottle. Some of those grains I had never heard of before such as triticale, millet, or grouse.
Aroma is fruit, bubblegum and slightly English Ale. The flavor is fruit, complex malts and a tart/slightly sweet finish.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of caramel malt, floral hops, light rye, & some fruit; Flavor of malt/biscuit, floral hops, buckwheat, citrus, and some caramel; Finish is dry & slightly bitter; Tasty - pretty decent.
Tasty blend of unique malts! Leans sweet as expected, but a good addition of hop bitterness. Dark Amber color. I encourage strange malt blends rather than just the unique hop blends.

Pours reddish copper with a one finger off white head with nice lacing. Aroma is of citrus, pine, bready malts, sweet malts, rye, earthy hops, light grassy hops, and light coffee. Taste is about the same as the aroma. Has a medium body with a creamy mouthfeel and a semi-moderately bitter, slightly dry, long finish. Overall, a pretty nice amber ale that is pretty well balanced, and drinkable.

Bottle shared by Dr Silverworm. Poured clear golden color with an average to large frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Medium to heavy complex citrus hop and grain aroma. Medium to full body with slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy sweet flavor with a medium to heavy complex sweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is an interesting good beer.

Bottle. Dark amber pour with a good head and lace. Citrus aroma upfront and sweet malt. Witht he hops used I expected and big citrus punch at 1st sip and was disappointed by it not being there right off. Lots more in here that just the hops. Nice malty body and mix of malt makes it a rougher drink than expected. After 1st glass, capped the rest as I got more work done and cam back 5 hours later. 2nd glass was much better and enjoyable with a nice citrus ending.

Pours a slightly cloudy, dark golden amber color with deep ruby red edges and a frothy yellowish beige head that very slowly settles into a thick, lasting ring. Excellent retention, lingering for the duration and completely coating the glass with sheets of soapy lacing.

I know that this beer is mostly about the malt bill but the hop presence is severely muted, hurting the overall aroma. Slightly earthy with some grassy resins but the nose of this beer is pretty bland. Very surprising for a Stone beer. Grainy with malted barley, subtle roast, dark bread and light sweetness. Caramel, toffee, blonde coffee, lightly charred toast and faint smokiness. Pretty boring.

Fuller body than expected and only slightly more interesting and flavorful than the nose suggests. Hop presence stands out a bit more with dry, sticky bitterness up front lingering over the heavy malt backbone into a dry finish. Grassy resins with pine sap and kind bud but again, the malts are the star here. Interesting balance of roast, earth and sweetness with hints of tobacco, leather, toast, lightly roasted coffee, oatmeal, caramel and chocolate. Slight boozy heat/sweetness on the finish. Overall, this beer is pretty odd. The hops show up more on the palate than in the aroma but are one dimensional, dry and bitter. The malt bill is intense but not all that complex which is surprising considering they used seven different grains. Not unpleasant, just kind of boring and slightly harsh. Hard to get through the bomber.

Bomber. Wheat aroma with rye, barley, floral and citrus hop notes. Pours amber colored with a thin tan head with good retention and good lacing. Starts with wheat, earthy rye and barley flavors. Finishes dry with floral and citrus hop flavor and slight bitterness. Interesting brew.
Pours amber with an off white head. Aroma is well hopped. Fairly smooth, with a nice hop bite.

22oz bottle, from Dutchs. Shared with Chris R, alexsdad06, and tmoney99. Up front in the nose, theres a surprisingly big amount of citrusy grapefruity hop. The malt bill is indeed rich, bready, kind of like a touch of rye or multigrain, but with a lot of hop over top. Its interesting. I dig it, especially now while its fresh with the big hop. Not sure how it would be once it ages a touch and the hop fades, but very nice balance as of now. Mostly clear red orange color. Thin off-white head, with some decent splotches of lace. Medium to bigger body. Drinks a bit lighter than 8.5%. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. Moderate-plus bitter taste, light to moderate sweet. I dunno, its pretty tasty. I dont think I would have minded enjoying a whole bottle of this with one of my sandwiches.

Pours a deep golden brown on tap with fluffy off-white head that dissipates to leave moderate lace. Aroma was mostly malty sweetness to me with maybe the slightest hint of pine on the back end. Taste is all malt, no hops there for me, a bit of booze to round it out. This series has not been very exciting for me.

Poured from a bottle. Deep ruby color. Thin khaki head. A good amount of lacing. Fruity aroma with a little bit of pine thrown in. Taste of raisins and bitter grapefruit. One of the better Stochastcity releases. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22. Spelled g-r-a-i-n-i-a-c. Pours a hazy dark amber with a loose creamy tan head. Big sweet orange and peppery rye nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Darkly toasted caramel with peppery rye and oranges on the mid palate. Long grainy finish.

Pours a ruby amber color with a thin khaki head. Hop, grain, caramel, toast, biscuit and raisin aroma. Raisin, toast, caramel, biscuit, grain and molasses flavors. Medium light body and moderate carbonation. Caramel, molasses and grain finish. Body is a bit this and its a bit more bland than expected with the malt bill.

Bottle from Ayottes
Deep copper with a beautiful reddish hue ans a bubbly creamy off white head that persists. Citrus and pine on the nose with bits of cereal earthy almost nutty maltiness with just a touch of burnt caramel. Rich cereal nutty earthy maltiness with plenty of c hop flavor to counter. Smooth bitterness. Different beer to be sure, but I enjoyed the hell out of it.
Pours a rich Amber color with a malty aroma. Taste is very dry and grainy. Flavors of hay, grass and a small nuttiness left on the palate after the swallow.

Deep mahogany pour with a frothy white head. Lots of sweet caramel, resiny hop, cereal, bready aromas jump from the glass. Flavors focused on the cereal type grains with some caramel, slight bittersweet finish that didnt last, touch of roast and bread. Maybe some wood in the backend. Mouthfeel was medium plus. A fun beer with lots of malt complexity and a punch of hops. Good stuff.

Pours deep mahogany into a tulip. Off-white head with good retention recedes leaving sheet lacing. Pepper and resin aromas. Sweet millet and pumpernickel upfront turning to hot resin and aged pit fruit before the lasting roasted nut and pith finish.
pretty much exactly what I though it would be - a strong hoppy slightly abrasive beer with a deep and complex malt profile. Nicely done.
The 1st rating... Pours a golden brown with small fizzy head. Aromas of citrus peel, hops, and a touch of grain. Flavors of hops, malts with a spicy finish. Hail...Hail...Colon Blow!
